facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 120 of 1955 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 120 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 25, 1949,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated March 25, 1949 of Madras High Court in Appeal No. 55 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 25, 1949, of the Madras High Court in Appeal No. 55 of 1946, arising out of the judgment and decree dated November 26, 1945,

facts.text: Madras High Court appeal arose from judgment dated November 26, 1945 of District Judge of Bellary in Original Suit No. 39 of 1943.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated November 26, 1945, of the Court of the District Judge of Bellary in Original Suit No. 39 of 1943. V. Viswanatha Sastri and K. R. Chaudhury for B. K. B. Naidu,

facts.text: Kari Veerappa executed will Exbt. P-2 on October 10, 1920.

anchor.surface_text: Kari Veerappa was the last male owner of the estate mentioned in his will, Exbt. P-2 a , which he executed on October 10, 1920. Under this will he authorised his wife Setra Veeravva, first defendant,

facts.text: Kari Veerappa authorised wife Setra Veeravva to adopt a son for continuation of his family.

anchor.surface_text: Under this will he authorised his wife Setra Veeravva, first defendant, to adopt a son for the purpose of companytinuation of his family as he had numberissue. The authority to adopt was in the following terms I have given her permission to adopt as many times as would be necessary,

facts.text: Kari Veerappa died on October 23, 1920.

anchor.surface_text: This gentle. man died on October 23, 1920. After his death, his widow made two attempts to adopt a son in accordance with his will. The first attempt was in 1939 which did number accomplish the purpose of the will as the person alleged to have been adopted died.

facts.text: Veeravva made first adoption attempt in 1939, adopted boy died.

anchor.surface_text: After his death, his widow made two attempts to adopt a son in accordance with his will. The first attempt was in 1939 which did number accomplish the purpose of the will as the person alleged to have been adopted died. The validity of this adoption was being questioned,

facts.text: Veeravva adopted second defendant Sesalvada Kotra Basayya on October 11, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Veeravva thereafter, on October 11, 1942, adopted second defendant, Sesalvada Kotra Basayya. Two documents in this companynection are on the record. The first document is Exbt. D-25 dated the 18th of September, 1942,

facts.text: Registered agreement to adopt second defendant Exbt. D-25 dated September 18, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: Two documents in this companynection are on the record. The first document is Exbt. D-25 dated the 18th of September, 1942, which was a registered agreement to adopt the second defendant. The second document is also a registered document,

facts.text: Registered deed of adoption dated June 23, 1943 stating adoption on October 11, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The second document is also a registered document, which is described as the deed of adoption and is dated June 23, 1943. This clearly states that on October 11, 1942, Veeravva had adopted the 2nd defendant. Reference was also made in this document to the agreement of September 18, 1942.

facts.text: Appellant, claiming to be nearest reversioner of Kari Veerappa, filed suit for declaration that adoption invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant claiming to be the nearest reversioner of Kari Veerappa filed the present suit asking for a declaration that the adoption of the second defendant by Veeravva was invalid and number binding on the appellant or the other reversioners to the estate of the late Kari Veerappa.

facts.text: District Judge of Bellary dismissed appellant's suit.

anchor.surface_text: The suit filed by the appellant was heard by the District Judge of Bellary who dismissed it. The appellant- appealed to the High Court of Madras. His appeal was dismissed and the decision of the District Judge was substantially affirmed.

facts.text: Madras High Court dismissed appellant's appeal and affirmed District Judge's decision substantially.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant- appealed to the High Court of Madras. His appeal was dismissed and the decision of the District Judge was substantially affirmed. The High Court did number allow companypensatory companyts granted by the District Judge, number did it agree with his finding that the appellant had failed to prove the relationship he had propounded

facts.text: High Court found appellant is a reversioner but not proved nearest.

anchor.surface_text: number did it agree with his finding that the appellant had failed to prove the relationship he had propounded and that lie was -not a reversioner at all, far less the nearest reversioner. In the opinion of the High Court, the appellant was a relative and a reversioner,

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court on substantial question of law regarding adoption validity.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is before us on a certificate granted by the High Court as according to that Court a substantial question of law arose in the case which was stated by it to be Is the adoption of the second defendant invalid, as the approval or companysent of the five trustees mentioned in paragraph 14 of the will of Kari Veerappa, Exbt. P-2 a  was number obtained

facts.text: Respondents raised preliminary objection that suit fails due to s.14 Hindu Succession Act, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: When this appeal came on for hearing the learned Advocate for the respondents took a preliminary objection that the suit filed by the plaintiff must in any event fail, having regard to the provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956  30 of 1956 , hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Hindu Succession Act, 1956 came into force on June 17, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Since the Act came into force on June 17, 1956, and the decision of the High Court was given on March 25, 1955, the question as to who was in actual possession of the estate of Veerappa did number arise for companysideration

facts.text: Agreement Exbt. D-25 stated Veeravva to remain in possession during lifetime despite adoption.

anchor.surface_text: But even on the adoption of the second defendant, the agreement to adopt dated September 18, 1942, stated that Veeravva was to remain in possession of her husbands estate during her life time in spite of the adoption.

facts.text: Written statement by Veeravva and second defendant admitted she was in sole possession up to date.

anchor.surface_text: In the written statement filed by Veeravva and the second defendant it was clearly stated in para. 6 thereof that Veeravva came into possession of her husbands property and that she recovered possession of the property companyered by the decree in 0. S. 20 of 1921

facts.text: Affidavit by second defendant admitted Veeravva in possession per agreement.

anchor.surface_text: An affidavit had been filed in this Court by the second defendant in which he has clearly admitted that Veeravva is still in possession of his adoptive fathers estate in pursuance of the agreement of September 18, 1942.

facts.text: Appellant disputed Veeravva's possession, claimed second defendant in possession.

anchor.surface_text: In para. 2 he had made the significant statement I understand that the possession of the suit properties has been and is number, in truth and in fact, with the alleged adopted son, the second petitioner. He is in possession of these properties and is dealing with them.

facts.text: Court held that even if adoption invalid, Veeravva possessed estate under s.14 HSA in broad sense including constructive possession.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case if the adoption was invalid, the full owner of Veerappas estate was his widow Veeravva and even if it be assumed that the second defendant was in actual possession of the estate his possession was merely permissive and Veeravva must be regarded as being in companystructive possession

facts.text: Court held appellant's suit not maintainable due to s.14 HSA even assuming invalid adoption.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, under the Act Veeravva becoming a full owner of her husbands estate, the suit companyld number succeed and the appeal must accordingly fail. In our opinion, the appellants suit was number maintainable, having regard to the provisions of s. 14 of the Act, even if it be assumed that there was numbervalid adoption of the second defendant.

facts.text: Veeravva recovered possession via decree in O.S. 20 of 1921.

anchor.surface_text: that she recovered possession of the property companyered by the decree in 0. S. 20 of 1921 on the file of the Subordinate Judges Court, Bellary, and that she had been in sole possession of the said property up-to- date

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 of the Act states- 14 1  Any property possessed by a female Hindu, whether acquired before or after the companymencement of this Act, shall be held by her as full owner thereof and number as a limited owner.  1  1940 F.C.R. 84. Explanation.-In this sub-section, property includes both movable and immovable property acquired by a female Hindu by inheritance or devise, or at a partition, or in lieu of maintenance or arrears of maintenance, or by gift from any person, whether a relative or number, before, at or after her marriage, or by her own skill or exertion, or by purchase or by prescription, or in any other manner whatsoever, and also any such property held by her as stridhana immediately before the companymencement of this Act.

holdings.text: It is well settled that an appellate court is entitled to take into consideration any change in the law.

anchor.surface_text: In, view of this submission we are of the opinion that the point raised by way of preliminary objection must first be considered and decided. It is well settled that an appellate court is entitled to take into consideration any change in the law  vide the case of Lachmeshwar Prasad Shukul v. Keshwar Lal Chaudhuri 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent that appellate courts consider post-lower court changes in law like HSA.

holdings.text: The provisions of s. 14 of the Hindu Succession Act apply to the facts of the present case even assuming the adoption was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents it was urged that the words any property possessed by a female Hindu did not refer merely to actual physical possession only but to ownership and possession in law as well. ... The word possessed is used in s. 14 in a broad sense and in the context possession means the state of owning or having in ones hands or power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets 'possessed' broadly including constructive possession based on High Court precedents; applies to widow's estate.

holdings.text: The words 'any property possessed by a female Hindu' in s.14(1) are to be interpreted in a broad sense including constructive possession or possession in law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts High Courts' (Andhra, Calcutta) view that 'possessed' means state of owning/having in power, not just physical; cites cases.

holdings.text: Even if the second defendant was in actual possession, his possession was merely permissive and Veeravva must be regarded as being in constructive possession.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case if the adoption was invalid, the full owner of Veerappas estate was his widow Veeravva and even if it be assumed that the second defendant was in actual possession of the estate his possession was merely permissive and Veeravva must be regarded as being in constructive possession

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumes invalid adoption; applies broad possession to facts where widow entitled to lifetime possession per agreement/admissions.

holdings.text: There is no material on the record by which it can reasonably be said that the provisions of sub-s. (2) of s. 14 of the Act applied to the present case.

anchor.surface_text: It was suggested that according to the will of Veerappa, Exbt. P2 a , in the properties mentioned in para. 1-of that will, Veeravva got only a restricted estate. The provisions of para. 4 of the will, however, make it clear that they would come into force only if the trustees mentioned in the will and Veeravva should disagree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Will para 4 conditional/not triggered; para 12 provides intestacy; agreement D-25 confers no restricted estate.

holdings.text: Illustration (f) to s.42 Specific Relief Act refers to a Hindu widow's limited estate and has no reference to a full owner; reversioner has no such right against full owner.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this is of no avail to the appellant, because Illustration f obviously refers to a Hindu widows estate and has no reference to a full owner. The right of a reversioner as one of the heirs under s. 42, Specific Relief Act, is limited to the question of preserving the estate of a limited owner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes pre-HSA limited estate rights from full ownership under s.14 HSA.

holdings.text: Under the Act Veeravva becoming a full owner of her husbands estate, the suit could not succeed and the appeal must accordingly fail. The appellants suit was not maintainable, having regard to the provisions of s. 14 of the Act, even if it be assumed that there was no valid adoption of the second defendant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, under the Act Veeravva becoming a full owner of her husbands estate, the suit could number succeed and the appeal must accordingly fail. In our opinion, the appellants suit was number maintainable, having regard to the provisions of s. 14 of the Act, even if it be assumed that there was numbervalid adoption of the second defendant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines s.14(1) application, broad possession, s.14(2) inapplicability; widow full owner renders challenge moot.

precedents.citation: Mt. Janki Kuer v. Chhathu Prasad 2

anchor.surface_text: Mt. Janki Kuer v. Chhathu Prasad 2  the Patna High Court took the view that the effect of ss. 14 and 15 of the Act was that a reversioner recognised as such under the Hindu law was numbermore a reversioner, as a female Hindu possessing any property, whether acquired before or after the companymencement of the Act, held number a limited estate but an absolute estate therein, and after the companying into force of the Act, he had numberright of reversion or any kind Of Spes successionsis. The High Courts of Calcutta, Andhra Pradesh and Madhya Pradesh have taken a view which does number support the view expressed by the Patna High Court in the aforesaid cases,

precedents.case_name: Mt. Janki Kuer v. Chhathu Prasad
precedents.cited_proposition: effect of ss. 14 and 15 of the Act was that a reversioner recognised as such under the Hindu law was no more a reversioner, female Hindu possessing property holds absolute estate, no right of reversion after Act

anchor.surface_text: Mt. Lukai v. Niranjan 3  dissented from the decisions of the Patna High Court in the above-mentioned cases. Indeed, the Patna High Court in the case of Harak Singh v. KailaSh Singh 1  overruled its previous decisions referred to above, and rightly pointed out that the object of the Act was to improve the legal status of Hindu women, enlarging their limited interest in property inherited or held by them to an absolute interest, provided they were in possession of the property when the Act came into force and, therefore, in a position to take advantage of its beneficial provisions but the Act was number intended to benefit alienees who with their eyes open purchased the property from the limited owners without justifying necessity before the Act came into force and at a time when the vendors had only a limited interest of Hindu women.

precedents.cited_proposition: dissented from the decisions of the Patna High Court

anchor.surface_text: Harak Singh v. KailaSh Singh 1  overruled its previous decisions referred to above, and rightly pointed out that the object of the Act was to improve the legal status of Hindu women, enlarging their limited interest in property inherited or held by them to an absolute interest, provided they were in possession of the property when the Act came into force and, therefore, in a position to take advantage of its beneficial provisions but the Act was number intended to benefit alienees who with their eyes open purchased the property from the limited owners without justifying necessity before the Act came into force and at a time when the vendors had only a limited interest of Hindu women.

precedents.cited_proposition: overruled previous Patna decisions; object of Act to improve status of Hindu women by enlarging limited interest to absolute if in possession, not to benefit pre-Act alienees

anchor.surface_text: Gaddam Venkayamma v. Gaddam Veerayya 1  Viswanatha Sastri, J., with whom Satyanarayana Raju, J., agreed, expressed the opinion that the word possessed in s. 14 refers to possession on the date when the Act came into force. companyrse, possession referred to in s. 14 need number be actual physical possession or personal occupation of the property by the Hindu female-but may be possession in law. The possession of a licensee, lessee or a mortgagee from the female owner or the possession of a guardian or a trustee or an agent of the female owner would be her possession for the purpose of s. 14.

precedents.cited_proposition: word possessed in s. 14 refers to possession on date Act came into force, in broad sense including constructive possession or possession in law, possession of licensee etc. is her possession
precedents.cited_holding: possessed means the state of owning or having in ones hands or power, includes possession by receipt of rents and profits

anchor.surface_text: Gostha Behari v. Haridas Samanta 2 , P. N. Mookherjee, J., expressed his opinion as to the meaning of the words any property possessed by a female Hindu in the following words- The opening words in property possessed by a female Hindu obviously mean that to companye within the purview of the section the property must be in possession of the female companycerned at the date of the companymencement of the Act. They clearly companytemplate the females possession when the Act came into force. That possession might have been either actual or companystructive or in any form recognised by law, but unless the female Hindu, whose limited estate in the disputed property is claimed to have been transformed into absolute estate under this particular section, was at least in such possession, taking the word possession in its widest companynotation, when the Act came into force, the section would number apply-.

precedents.cited_proposition: any property possessed by a female Hindu means property in her possession at commencement of Act, actual or constructive or any form recognised by law
precedents.cited_holding: unless the female Hindu was at least in such possession, taking the word possession in its widest connotation, when the Act came into force, the section would not apply
